com.github.blackjak34.compute.entity.tile

Class TileEntityComputer

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity
      • com.github.blackjak34.compute.entity.tile.TileEntityComputer

  • public class TileEntityComputer
extends net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity
    The emulator component of the Computer block. Fully emulates an old 6502 processor from the '70s. Players can feed information into the computer through the GUI made available by BlockComputer.
    Since:
    1.0

    • Field Detail

      • floppyInDrive

        private boolean floppyInDrive
        Whether or not this computer currently has a floppy disk in its drive. Used for rendering and eject checks.

      • floppyDataDir

        private java.lang.String floppyDataDir
        The data directory of the floppy disk currently in this computer. This is explicitly set to null when there is no floppy disk in the computer to make errors more obvious.

      • cursorX

        public int cursorX
        The current column on the screen that the cursor is occupying. Used for rendering and putting data into the screen buffer.

      • cursorY

        public int cursorY
        The current row on the screen that the cursor is occupying. Used for rendering and putting data into the screen buffer.

      • keyBuffer

        private byte[] keyBuffer
        A 16-byte long circular key buffer that stores keypresses sent by the client. This array should be indexed using keyBufferStart and keyBufferPos.

      • keyBufferStart

        private int keyBufferStart
        Specific indexes used for reading data and writing data into/out of the circular key buffer.

      • keyBufferPos

        private int keyBufferPos
        Specific indexes used for reading data and writing data into/out of the circular key buffer.

      • screenBuffer

        private byte[][] screenBuffer
        The screen buffer, for an 80x50 character screen size. Writing a byte into this buffer will display a character on the screen accordingly.

      • registerA

        private byte registerA
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1.)

      • registerX

        private byte registerX
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1.)

      • registerY

        private byte registerY
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1.)

      • stackPointer

        private byte stackPointer
        The registers within the 6502. Register A acts as the 'accumulator' and is primarily the target of most calculations, Register X and Y are mostly used for looping over data within memory and storing values temporarily, and the stack pointer stores the address on page 1 where the next item on the stack may be stored. (The most recent value pushed to the stack may be found by reading the memory at location stackPointer - 1.)

      • flagCarry

        private boolean flagCarry
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • flagZero

        private boolean flagZero
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • flagInterrupt

        private boolean flagInterrupt
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • flagDecimal

        private boolean flagDecimal
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • flagBreak

        private boolean flagBreak
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • flagOverflow

        private boolean flagOverflow
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • flagSign

        private boolean flagSign
        The processor status flags. These flags are (within the actual 6502) stored as individual bits within a register dedicated to holding them, but this implementation uses boolean variables for simplicity. Bit 5 is unused and always remains a logical 1, leaving seven flags. They are, in ascending order, the carry, zero, interrupt-disable, decimal-mode, break, overflow, and sign flags.

      • programCounter

        private int programCounter
        The program counter. While at first glance this appears to be another register, the program counter is actually 16 bits instead of 8 to allow it to address up to 65536 bytes of memory. Every time the tile entity is updated (once per tick), the instruction at the location pointed to by the program counter is executed and the program counter is incremented by the length of that particular instruction in order to point it to the next one.

      • memory

        private byte[] memory
        The memory of the computer. This is represented with a byte array 65536 bytes in length.

      • state

        private StateComputer state
        The current state of the computer. This state may be 'RESET', 'HALT', or 'RUN'. While the computer only executes instructions while its state is RUN, RESET and HALT also serve to differentiate between the two settings for the front texture of the computer block. (see BlockComputer and StateComputer)

      • creationTime

        private long creationTime
        The world time when this tile entity was created. This value is subtracted from the current world time in order to produce the amount of time that this emulator has existed for.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TileEntityComputer

        public TileEntityComputer()
        An empty constructor that Forge can use to do some fancy reflection jazz on this TileEntity. Don't delete this or use it in actual code.

      • TileEntityComputer

        public TileEntityComputer(long creationTime)
        The constructor for an emulator instance. Fills the memory with #$FF and saves the current time as the time that this computer was created.
        Parameters:
        creationTime - The world time when this TileEntity was created

    • Method Detail

      • shouldRefresh

        public boolean shouldRefresh(net.minecraft.block.Block oldBlock,
                             net.minecraft.block.Block newBlock,
                             int oldMeta,
                             int newMeta,
                             net.minecraft.world.World world,
                             int x,
                             int y,
                             int z)
        Determines whether the TileEntity should be regenerated when the block id/metadata changes. Obviously, we don't want the metadata to regen this because we use it for setting the external block appearance.
        Overrides:
        shouldRefresh in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • getDescriptionPacket

        public net.minecraft.network.Packet getDescriptionPacket()
        Retrieves a Packet to send over the network to the client to sync the serverside TileEntity to the clientside TileEntity. This is extremely inefficient as it sends all of the data about this TileEntity every time a key is pressed in the GUI, but this also needs to send all of the data as it is called to initialize the data in the clientside version. Most likely a custom packet implementation to avoid this will come in the near future.
        Overrides:
        getDescriptionPacket in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • onDataPacket

        public void onDataPacket(net.minecraft.network.NetworkManager networkManager,
                         net.minecraft.network.play.server.S35PacketUpdateTileEntity packet)
        Handles what to do on the clientside after the description packet is recieved. All this function does is load the data out of the packet.
        Overrides:
        onDataPacket in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • testBit

        private static boolean testBit(byte target,
                               int offset)
        Tests a specific bit within a byte and returns its value as a boolean.
        Parameters:
        target - The byte to be tested
        offset - Which bit to test
        Returns:
        Whether or not that bit is set

      • readMemory

        public byte readMemory(int index)
        A helper function for accessing memory through an integer variable. If the value of the index is greater than the amount of memory available or less than zero then the function returns 0xFF.
        Parameters:
        index - The memory location to be read
        Returns:
        The byte at that location

      • writeMemory

        public void writeMemory(int index,
                        byte value)
        Similar in function to writeMemory, but writes the specified value to the memory location instead of reading from it. If the index is invalid, the function simply returns.
        Parameters:
        index - The memory location to be written to
        value - The value to write

      • pushStack

        private void pushStack(byte value)
        Pushes a value to the stack. Adds 256 (decimal) to the stack pointer to put it on page 1, assigns the memory location at that address to the specified value, and decrements the stack pointer. This function does NOT check if the stack is full, and the stack pointer WILL overflow if pushed too frequently.
        Parameters:
        value - The value to be pushed.

      • pullStack

        private byte pullStack()
        Pulls a value off of the stack. Increments the stack pointer, adds 256 (decimal) to it to put it on page 1, and returns the byte stored at that address. This function does NOT check if the stack is empty, and the stack pointer WILL underflow if pulled too frequently.
        Returns:
        The value pulled off of the stack

      • setProgramCounter

        public void setProgramCounter(int value)
        Sets the program counter to the value and wraps it if it is too large. This has the effect of changing the code that the emulator is currently executing to the new location.
        Parameters:
        value - The address to jump to

      • setState

        public void setState(StateComputer state)
        Sets the computer's current state (see StateComputer). The state should always be changed through this function instead of directly because the metadata is also set accordingly.
        Parameters:
        state - The new state to use

      • getState

        public StateComputer getState()
        Returns the current state of this computer, used to update the lights in the GUI.
        Returns:
        The current state of this emulator

      • isFloppyInDrive

        public boolean isFloppyInDrive()
        Returns whether or not this computer currently has a floppy disk in its disk drive.
        Returns:
        Whether or not there is a floppy in the drive

      • ejectFloppy

        public void ejectFloppy()
        If there is a floppy disk in the computer and the world is not remote (the code is running on the server), sets isFloppyInDrive to false and floppyDataDir to 'null'. A floppy disk item with the old value of floppyDataDir is then spawned in the world and the block metadata is set to no longer display a floppy in the drive.

      • insertFloppy

        public void insertFloppy(java.lang.String dataDirectory)
        Sets floppyInDrive to true, floppyDataDir to the specified data directory, and the block metadata to display a floppy disk in the drive.
        Parameters:
        dataDirectory - The data directory of the floppy disk

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this object. This includes the values of the A, X, and Y registers, as well as the stack pointer, and the number of ticks that this computer has existed for.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A string representation of this emulator instance

      • writeToNBT

        public void writeToNBT(net.minecraft.nbt.NBTTagCompound data)
        Saves all of the data stored within this TileEntity into NBT format. Automatically called by Forge to save the data when the chunk containing this TileEntity is unloaded (by a player moving too far away, a player leaving the world, or the server shutting down).This function also appears to be called at arbitrary times during the game, so don't use it for running code that should be run on chunk unload.
        Overrides:
        writeToNBT in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • readFromNBT

        public void readFromNBT(net.minecraft.nbt.NBTTagCompound data)
        Loads all of the data stored within an NBTTagCompound into this TileEntity accordingly. Automatically called by Forge to load the data when the chunk containing this TileEntity is loaded (by a player moving closer, a player joining the world, or the server starting up). This function also appears to be called at arbitrary times during the game, so don't use it for running code that should be run on chunk load.
        Overrides:
        readFromNBT in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • updateEntity

        public void updateEntity()
        This function is automatically called by Forge once per tick for all loaded TileEntitys. This is the main work function of the emulator; it executes an instruction every time the TileEntity is updated. You may also call this function manually if you want the emulator to asynchronously execute a command.
        Overrides:
        updateEntity in class net.minecraft.tileentity.TileEntity

      • readImmAddress

        private int readImmAddress(int addressToRead)
        Reads and returns a little-endian two byte address from the given location in memory.
        Parameters:
        addressToRead - The location to read from
        Returns:
        An absolute address that was read from memory

      • pullImmAddress

        private int pullImmAddress()
        Pulls and returns a two-byte address from the stack. The low byte is pulled first, so when storing an address on the stack the high byte should be pushed first.
        Returns:
        An absolute address that was pulled from the stack

      • setSignZeroFlags

        private void setSignZeroFlags(byte testValue)
        Sets the sign flag if the test value is negative and the zero flag if the test value is zero.
        Parameters:
        testValue - The value to be tested

      • performAddition

        private void performAddition(int addressOfValue,
                             boolean subtract)
        Seeks a byte value at the address given and adds it to the accumulator while accounting for and setting flags appropriately. Subtraction can also be performed by specifying so in the second parameter.
        Parameters:
        addressOfValue - The address of the value to add/subtract
        subtract - Whether subtraction should be performed or not

      • performComparation

        private void performComparation(int addressOfValue,
                                int valueComparedTo)
        Seeks a byte value at the address given and compares it to the value given. This sets the overflow, carry, sign, and zero flags similarly as if a subtraction had occurred but no actual changes are made to the registers.
        Parameters:
        addressOfValue - The address of the value to compare
        valueComparedTo - The value to compare the first to

      • getComputerTime

        private long getComputerTime()
        Calculates how long this computer has existed for, in ticks by subtracting the current world time from the time when this computer was created.
        Returns:
        The number of ticks that this computer has existed for

      • getCharAt

        public byte getCharAt(int screenColumn,
                      int screenRow)
        Returns the byte value at the specified location in the screen buffer.
        Parameters:
        screenColumn - The x coord of the byte
        screenRow - The y coord of the byte
        Returns:
        The byte at the specified coords

      • onKeyPressed

        public void onKeyPressed(char keyPressed)
        This function is called by this TIleEntity's Container upon receiving a MessageKeyPressed packet. It handles the keypress accordingly and then marks the entity to be synced.
        Parameters:
        keyPressed - The key that was pressed by a client

      • onButtonClicked

        public void onButtonClicked(int buttonId)
        This function is called by this TileEntity's Container upon receiving a MessageButtonClicked packet. It handles the button click accordingly and then marks the entity to be synced. If one of the three state buttons were pressed then the state is set, or if the floppy disk eject button was pressed then the floppy disk (if there is one in the drive) is ejected.
        Parameters:
        buttonId - The id of the button that was pressed

      • interpretLine

        public void interpretLine()
        A big function that handles keypresses from clients once they reach the serverside. This has a shoddy pseudo-assembler built into it for testing purposes and will certainly not be in the release version of the mod.

      • nextLine

        private void nextLine()
        Moves the cursor down one line and all the way to the left.
